citeinfo.origin: Great Britain Historical Geographical Information System
citeinfo.title: Administrative Counties of England and Wales 1951

descript.abstract: These are digital boundaries for the system of counties essentially created by the 1889 Local Government Act and continuing to exist until 1974. Their initial primary focus was the administration of education. During the twentieth century, they can be treated as aggregates of local government districts, although note that administratively County Boroughs were independent of the counties they were geographically part of. This file represents the system as it was used to report the 1951 Census of Population, and does not separately identify County Boroughs.
descript.purpose: The mission of the Great Britain Historical GIS Project is to provide a systematic spatial framework for historical information about Britain.
descript.supplinf: Gregory, I, Bennett, C, Gilham, V., and Southall, H. 2002. The Great Britain Historical GIS Project: from maps to changing human geography.' The Cartographic Journal, Vol. 39, No. 1, p. 37-49. Southall, H 2012, 'Rebuilding the Great Britain Historical GIS, part 2: a geo-spatial ontology of administrative units' Historical Methods: A Journal of Quantitative and Interdisciplinary History, vol 45, no. 3, pp. 119-134. DOI: 10.1080/01615440.2012.664101

idinfo.accconst: To promote awareness of our work and to provide a public benefit, the University of Portsmouth and the Great Britain Historical GIS makes these county boundaries, but not other more detailed boundaries, available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International (CC BY-SA 4.0): https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/. This does not mean they are in the public domain: (1) You must give appropriate credit, provide a link to the license, and indicate if changes were made. You may do so in any reasonable manner, but not in any way that suggests that the University of Portsmouth or the Great Britain Historical GIS endorses you or your use. (2) The share-alike requirement means that anything you publish using these boundaries must also be under a CC BY-SA license. In particular, if you use these boundaries to map your attribute data, you must make the attribute data available under that license. For unrestricted commercial licensing, contact gbhgis@port.ac.uk.
idinfo.useconst: Copies of the boundary data may not be passed on to other users; each user must obtain their own copy of the data from the University of Portsmouth or from a data library authorised to distribute, who are required to maintain a record of users to whom the data have been supplied. Data may be used to create paper maps, non-georeferenced raster images or PDF files, provided they include a copyright notice and acknowledgment. Geo-referenced vector data in any format may not be disseminated by any method, including online downloads or data feeds. For full details see copyright license included with authorised copies of the data.

cntaddr.address: Department of Geography. Buckingham Building, Lion Terrace,

citeinfo.origin: Great Britain Historical Geographical Information System
citeinfo.title: Great Britain Historical Geographical Information System

procstep.procdesc: These boundaries were created in four stages: (1) Systematic digitisation of parish boundaries from Ordnance Survey county administrative diagrams published c. 1910. Those maps are generally at the scale of two miles to one inch, but the County of London was mapped from maps at six inches to one mile scale. This work was mainly by Victoria Gilham, working at Queen Mary University of London (QMUL) in 1997-9. (2) The 1911 digital parish boundaries were then modified to create mapping of parish boundaries at later dates including 1951 by Victoria Gilham in 1999-2000 at QMUL using (a) listings of boundary changes in census and vital registration reports and (b) later editions of the Ordnance Survey county administrative diagrams, which were published approximately every 10 years. (3) Those parish boundary lines which were also boundaries of Local Government Districts were selected out, and any additional district boundary lines added, drawing on the same sources. (4) The above work formed part of a single large system which aimed to represent changing boundaries in continuous time, holding boundary lines as individual arcs which were to be assembled into polygon geometries using software written in Arc Macro Language. The current polygon file tailored to a particular census date was created at the University of Portsmouth in 2001-4, by Nick Burton and Paula Aucott. The Local Government District boundary lines were selected out and amalgamated to create Administrative County polygons based on the list of Local Government Districts within individual counties given in the 1951 Census.

enttyp.enttypd: administrative county boundaries of Great Britain from 1951

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: This value is a unique identifier from our gazetteer. The g_unit value can be used to identify the same unit in different years even if the name/boundary/status of the unit has changed.
Name of unit at this date

Status of name: P = Preferred or O = Official Equates to "G_NAME_STATUS" in gazetteer. As far as possible all unit names are the Preferred English name at the date given in the file name. Where this was unavailable they have been assigned their Preferred Welsh name in that year. Where the name status is given as 'O' this indicates it was the preferred official name at this particular date, although another name later replaced it as the preferred name.
Language of name: eng = English, cym = Welsh

Administrative unit type of the unit: ADM_CNTY = Administrative County, PR_CNTY = Poor Law County/Registration County, ANC_CNTY = Ancient County Equates to "G_UNIT_TYPE" in gazetteer. The Unittype value is the administrative unit type for this unit at the date given in the file name.
